**Preface to the *Jade Exegesis and Phonetic Gloss of the Supreme Clarity Great Cavern Perfected Scripture***

Composed by Chen Jingyuan, Disciple of the Three Radiant Caverns of the Great Cavern, Perfected Master of True Stillness, and Recipient of the Purple Robe

The *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* hold a title of solemn reverence, standing foremost among the Three Caverns’ treasured scriptures. Its numinous verses and secret incantations, sealed in jade tablets and concealed in hidden writings, are recorded in full detail.

Since the Western City’s Lord of Total Perfection and the Southern Culmen’s Purple Prime Lady bestowed it upon the Perfected One of Pure Emptiness, who in turn transmitted it to Madame Wei of Southern Marchmount, it has been said: “Should you not dwell in the mountains, concealing yourself in pure retreat and voiding the center through breath-regulation, then the *Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* must not be recited recklessly.”

The reason for this is that its wondrous tones resonate through nine heavens, its true sounds soar in lofty chant. The qi of its text intermingles with the Jade Void in profound mystery, its rosy savor harmonizes with the Great Yang in full splendor. When lips move to utter it, jade efflorescence instantly arrives; when its sacred lines are intoned, one joins in covenant with the Most High. In stillness, with hands clasped in reverence, the Purple Chamber reveals itself; in focused contemplation of one’s aspirations, all kindred spirits respond in resonance.

Thus, the seven ancestors gain blessings, receive registers of immortal palaces, transcend the ranks of hidden ghosts, and together feast in the Vermilion Mound. This scripture’s sublimity soars, steering the chariot of dawn’s ascent, riding the Way of the luminous dragon—far beyond the reach of those mired in the dust of mundane custom.

Should one recite it while still entangled in worldly affairs, the Three Officials and the Northern Emperor will disrupt its tones, and the radiant listener, tainted by impure qi, will fail to attain the resplendent resonance of Supreme Clarity or harmonize the voice with the numinous chambers of the Purple Culmen.

The *Azure Essentials and Purple Writ* of the Central Yellow Venerable Lord states: “To behold the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* is to ascend to heaven in broad daylight.” Yet some who cultivate it accumulate years without fruition and then claim the scripture is not true. This is entirely due to their names lacking inscription on the Golden Tablet of the Eastern Flower or the Jade Slip of the Golden Watchtower. The true numina do not descend for them, and instead, celestial demons approach, resulting in no responsive efficacy. Though they may obtain spirit-scriptures, they will never succeed.

Had they first memorialized the Golden Tablet to the Azure Palace and presented the Jade Slip to the Thearch-Emperor, securing the attendance of the Golden Dawn Jade Lads and the Western Flower Jade Maidens to guard the numinous text, and had all heavens and earths, the three realms, praised and chanted its verses ten thousand times—how could they not have evoked the response of the jade chariot and purple carriage?

Since this scripture descended into the world, only the Perfected Yang and Xu of Mount Juqu and Master Sima the Refiner of Mount Wangwu, along with successive generations of eminent Daoist adepts, have adhered to its precepts, transmitting it through sworn covenants. The oral instructions for its recitation and the esoteric subtleties of its integration were secretly imparted, enabling them to inscribe their names in the golden register and tread the luminous paths of Supreme Clarity.

Yet today, the true wind has scattered and faded, false recluses dwell in mountain retreats, the standards of the Dao are unheard, the rites between master and disciple have lapsed, and the teachings have declined—nothing is more grievous than this.

Jingyuan left home in childhood, sought the Dao in youth, and wandered for thirty years, presiding over the essentials for over a decade. In old age, I returned to Mount Mao, built a hut, and engaged in repentance. I lamented my meager karmic affinity for the Dao and the weight of my worldly karma. Though I diligently studied the scriptures, I never encountered a true master. How could I dare unseal and recite the Cavern Scripture?

Thus, I purified body and mind, devoted myself to reverence and purity, and broadly sought ancient editions. First, I examined and verified them myself, poring over them in silence, repeatedly analyzing and constructing their meaning. Not a single phrase or character was overlooked.

Yet where two interpretations clashed, my perplexity only deepened—such as the case of *fa* (發) being miswritten as *fa yan* (發煙). Or where characters were altered in their components or forms, becoming confused and inconsistent—such as *qi* (栖) written as *@*, or *@* written as *ge* (歌).

This is because private copyists and illicit transmissions have perpetuated errors through successive generations. I have therefore taken the editions used by earlier practitioners—the Three Caverns Dharma Master, Master of Mystical Observation, Zhu Ziying, and the Three Caverns Dharma Master, Grand Master of Profound Mystery, Huangfu Xiji, both reciters of the Cavern Scripture and contemporaries of the Tiansheng era—as well as the editions preserved at Mount Mao’s repository. Comparing them with the hidden writings, I have compiled this phonetic gloss and exegesis, elucidating discrepancies and roughly resolving doubts. I dare not present this as definitive Dharma teaching, but merely record what I have examined for my own reference.

After three months of purifying my heart in retreat, I transcribed a copy of the *Jade Exegesis of the Cavern Scripture*, which I now reverently contemplate morning and evening. I await the numinous ones to bestow it according to the proper precepts, thereby fulfilling my long-cherished aspiration.

**Jade Exegesis and Phonetic Gloss of the Supreme Clarity Great Cavern Perfected Scripture**

The phonetic glosses for the *Hidden Writ of the Jade Concealment of the Demolishing-Mara Divine Wisdom*, the *Jade Annotations of the Dao Lord*, the *Cinnabar Chapters of the Purple Writ*, the *Returning to the Origin Supreme Method*, and the *Hundred Spirits Supreme Method* are provided herein.

*Jue* (訣) means “oral instructions,” pronounced *jué* (决). Ancient editions wrote it as *jué* (决), but later scribes altered it to *jué* (訣). Other instances follow this pattern.

*Yan jing* (晏景): the first character is pronounced *yàn* (宴). In ancient scriptures, *yan* (晏) and *yan* (宴) were interchangeable. Other instances follow this pattern.

*Yan qin* (晏寝): the Mount Mao edition writes it as *qu qin* (曲寝).

*Yu han* (玉翰): pronounced *hú àn* (胡岸切). The same character appears later in the text.

Jade-like rings (*juéjué*), rhyming with *yāng* (央), as seen in *Phonetic Glosses of All Daoist Scriptures* by Shi Chong, Grand Master of the Grand Clarity Abbey and Tang Court Gentleman for Splendid Happiness.

*Rǎngjù* (攘據): the first character is pronounced *rǔ yáng qiè* (汝羊切), the second *jū yù qiè* (居御切), meaning "to grasp."

*Zhàngfān* (杖幡): the first character is pronounced *zhí liàng qiè* (直亮切), meaning "to hold." Alternatively written as *仗* (*zhàng*), same pronunciation.

*Shèxié* (攝邪): pronounced *sì jiē qiè* (似嗟切), ancient editions wrote it as *邪*.

*Xílào* (檄落): the first character is pronounced *xíng dí qiè* (刑狄切), written as *激* (*jī*); in ancient calendars, it may also be written as *敷*.

*Yúnao* (云璈): pronounced *áo* (遨). Shi Chong states: "a great zither."

*Bǎihé héchàng* (百和合唱): pronounced *chì liàng qiè* (赤亮切), or written as *咽*. Shi Chong states: "should be written as *烟* (*yān*)."

*Jīwú* (激無): the first character is pronounced *gǔ lì qiè* (古歷切).

*Sìyú* (四嵎): pronounced *yú* (隅).

*Xùnpèi* (迅辔): the first character has two pronunciations, *jùn* (峻) and *xìn* (信), meaning "swift"; the second is pronounced *bīng mèi qiè* (兵媚切).

*Zhěngkòng* (整控): the first character is pronounced *zhī yǐng qiè* (之郢切), the second *kǔ gòng qiè* (苦贡切).

*Liúpàn* (流盼): pronounced *pǔ xiàn qiè* (普苋切), ancient editions wrote it as *眄*. Shi Chong pronounces it *miàn* (面).

*Xiéshén piāo jīn pō* (协神飘津坡): Shi Chong writes it as *协晨* (*xié chén*).

*Qiānzhǐ* (褰趾): the first character is pronounced *qù yān qiè* (去焉切), the second *zhǐ* (止), meaning "foot." *褰* may also be written as *骞*.

*Zǐpíng* (紫軿): pronounced *píng* (瓶), meaning "chariot."

*Yānsǎ* (烟洒): pronounced *suǒ xià qiè* (所下切). Shi Chong gives two pronunciations: *suǒ qǐ qiè* (所绮切) and *suǒ jì qiè* (所寄切), meaning "to scatter" or "to fall."

*Bāmíng* (八冥): pronounced *míng* (溟).

*Miàoguān* (妙观): pronounced *gǔ duàn qiè* (古段切).

*Bù běiyuán* (步北元): the Mount Mao edition writes it as *涉北元* (*shè běiyuán*).

*Duōrì* (掇日): the first character is pronounced *duō huó qiè* (多活切).

*Liángēng* (连更): pronounced *gēng* (庚).

*Qīqī* (凄凄): pronounced *qī* (妻), or written as *凄*.

*Mǎngmǎng* (莽莽): pronounced *mò dǎng qiè* (莫党切), describing a vast and boundless expanse.

*Shùlái* (数来): the first character is pronounced *sè jù qiè* (色句切).

*Chóngxū guǎn* (重虚馆): Shi Chong writes *馆* as *观* (*guàn*).

*Yùsuǐ* (玉髓): pronounced *xī wěi qiè* (息委切).

*Cānwén* (参闻): the first character is pronounced *cāng hán qiè* (仓含切); the second is pronounced as in *shēng cān tóng* (声参同).

*Jiānshì* (监试): the first character is pronounced *gǔ xián qiè* (古衔切), meaning "to oversee"; the second character is the same as in *jiān tíng* (监庭).

*Zàishèng* (载胜): pronounced *shēng* (升). Shi Chong writes it as *戴胜* (*dàishèng*).

*Bǐngjiǎn* (秉简): the first character is pronounced *bǔ yǒng qiè* (补永切), meaning "to hold."

*Láiguān* (来冠): pronounced *gǔ wàn qiè* (古玩切).

*Huífēng* (回风): the first character is pronounced *hú wēi qiè* (胡隈切). The *Shuowen* states it means "to turn"; the vulgar writing *迥* (*jiǒng*) is incorrect. Formerly written as *徊* (*huái*), describing a lingering, non-advancing motion. The *Shuowen* originally wrote it as *裴回* (*péihuí*), meaning "loose robes," capturing the sense of their billowing. Other instances follow this pattern.

*Chuòwù* (啜误): the first character is pronounced *zhū duō qiè* (株多切), meaning "to chatter endlessly." Written as *掇* (*duō*) is incorrect.

*Píngshēng* (平生): as defined in the *Shuowen*, "to cease."

Head-crown: pronounced *gǔ wàn qiè* (古玩切), a general term for ceremonial headdresses. Other instances follow this pattern.

Celestial Shore: pronounced *yù bēi qiè* (昱悲切), the edge of water.

Thin Clouds: the first character is pronounced *bó* (博), meaning "to press close."

Four Ridges: originally written as *领* (*lǐng*); subsequent instances follow this.

Double Doors: the first character is pronounced *zhí lóng qiè* (直龙切), the second *fēi* (非). Originally written as *扉* (*fēi*); some pronounce it *pái* (排), and *排* may also be pronounced *fēi* (扉). Other instances follow this pattern.

Beast Galloping: pronounced *chǒu yǐng qiè* (丑郢切).

Human Intertwining: pronounced *hú gù qiè* (胡故切); the vulgar writing *无* (*wú*) is incorrect.

Dry Radiance Essence: a name for the Minor Lad of the Grand Tenuity; also written as *Thousand Radiance Essence*.

Divine Banner: pronounced *hū wéi qiè* (呼为切), a type of banner. Some write it as *魔* (*mó*), which is incorrect.

Lingering: former versions uniformly wrote *徘徊* (*páihuái*); now all follow the *Shuowen* and are amended to *裴回* (*péihuí*). No further pronunciations are provided hereafter.

Whirlwind Wheel: the first character is pronounced *bì yáo qiè* (必遥切).

Lush Grass: pronounced *wū wài qiè* (乌外切), describing the luxuriance of vegetation.

Luxuriant: the first character is pronounced *wū dǒng qiè* (乌董切), the second *yú gài qiè* (於盖切); subsequent instances follow this.

Primal Yang Department Gate of Life: some versions write *Metropolis Gate of Life*.

Attending the Bright Window: Shi Chong writes it as *窗* (*chuāng*), pronounced *chū jiāng qiè* (初江切). Some versions write *聪* (*cōng*).

Infant Obscurity: originally written as *蒙* (*méng*); subsequent instances follow this.

Bright Gaze: pronounced *pǔ xiàn qiè* (普苋切). The *Shuowen* cites the *Book of Songs*: "Fair eyes gaze brightly." Ancient versions write *盼* (*pàn*) and *眄* (*miǎn*) interchangeably as *眄* (*miǎn*). The *Shuowen* defines *眄* as "eyes half-closed" or "sidelong glance," which conflicts with *盼*. Later interpretations resolve this by context.

Music Master: the first character is pronounced *luò* (洛); subsequent instances follow this.

Dissolution of Form: pronounced *hú mǎi qiè* (胡买切), meaning "enlightenment."

Four Emanations: Shi Chong pronounces it *shí yì qiè* (食亦切); some write it as *四谢* (*sìxiè*), which is incorrect.

Lofty Celestial Promontory: Shi Chong pronounces it *qí* (奇), meaning "curved bank." Some versions write *琦* (*qí*).

Roaring and Shouting: some write it as *咤* (*zhà*), pronounced *zhī jiā qiè* (知加切) or *zhì jià qiè* (陟嫁切). The *Shuowen* defines *叱* (*chì*) as "anger." *咄* (*duō*) is pronounced *dāng mò qiè* (当没切). The *Shuowen* defines it as "rebuke" or "scolding."

Sighing Moment: the first character is pronounced *zī yā qiè* (咨鸦切). The *Shuowen* defines it as "to sigh." Some interpret it as "grief" or pronounce it *qù yǐng qiè* (去颖切).

Swift: pronounced *shì zhú qiè* (式竹切), meaning "rapid" or "to run." Originally written as *鲦* (*tiáo*). The *Shuowen* defines it as "black-dyed silk that turns white" or "black color."

Sudden: pronounced *xū wù qiè* (许勿切). The *Shuowen* defines it as "something blown into motion."

Iron Bear: pronounced *bān mí qiè* (斑麋切).

Heavenly Ape: pronounced *jué fù qiè* (厥缚切), a celestial beast. Some versions write *攫* (*jué*).

Devouring Poison: pronounced *tú làn qiè* (徒滥切), meaning "to eat."

Brilliance: Shi Chong pronounces it *hú liǎo qiè* (胡了切) or *pò* (魄).

*Bā*: Shi Chong pronounces it *bā* (巴). According to the *Secrets Concealed by the Perfected*, the ghostly minister of the Northern Fengdu who governs souls is named *Four Celestial Brilliance-Bā*.

Collapse: pronounced *dù huí qiè* (杜回切). Shi Chong states the character should be written as *墤* (*tuí*).

Eclipse Radiance: the first character is pronounced *yī jiǎn qiè* (衣检切). Shi Chong states the first character should be written as *蚀* (*shí*), meaning "the sun and moon encroaching upon each other."

**Highest Celestial Jade Vacuity Lord’s Scripture of the Dao, First Chapter**

Long Covenant of One Revolution: ancient versions write *壹* (*yī*).

Seven Generations: some versions write *Seven Ancestors*.

Leisurely Retreat: some versions write *关* (*guān*).

Ascending Brahma: pronounced *wén chéng qiè* (闻承切). Ancient versions write *陵* (*líng*) and *凌* (*líng*) interchangeably as *凌* (*líng*); subsequent instances follow this.

Lifespan Unfolds Jade Orchid: some versions write *简* (*jiǎn*).

Eight Luminaries: some versions write *晖* (*huī*).

Following the Wind, Roots Depart, Bases Shift to Reach Transformation and Enter the Mysterious: some versions write *迁棋达变入玄元* (*qiān qí dá biàn rù xuán yuán*), and one version includes the two characters *元素* (*yuánsù*), which some readers connect to the following line as: *Primal Essence Highest Celestial Divine Aurora Jade Clarity King*. The Mao Shan manuscript omits *元素*. This translation follows the Mao Shan manuscript.

Male and Female Entrust Spirit to Transformation: some versions write *奇* (*qí*) for *寄* (*jì*).

Hundred Primes: pronounced *qí hún qiè* (奇混切). Ancient versions write *混* (*hùn*) as *矫* (*jiǎo*). All ascend to the Imperial Hall Assembly. According to the *Jade Annotations of the Dao Lord*: *Yì* (易) means "goodness," and is the name of the northwestern gate of the Nine Heavens. Only after passing through the Gate of *Yì* may one ascend to the Assembly Chamber of the Imperial Hall. Here, though the character *室* (*shì*) harmonizes with the preceding rhyme, the *Jade Annotations* indicate *会* (*huì*) is correct.

Wave-Reaching Terrace: some versions write *彼建台* (*bǐ jiàn tái*).

**Highest August Jade Vacuity Lord’s Scripture of the Dao, Second Chapter**

Flaming: pronounced *yàn* (艳), meaning "radiance."

A Thousand Kalpas Begin One Cycle: some versions write *Ten Kalpas Begin One Cycle*.

**August Jade Emperor Lord’s Scripture of the Dao, Third Chapter**

The Jade Emperor possesses the Darkest Highest Banner, which commands the steps of the Nine Heavens. The Mao Shan manuscript omits the character *之* (*zhī*).

Seven Awakenings Uphold the Dao’s Numerology: According to the *Jade Annotations of the Dao Lord*, the Seven Awakenings deeply comprehend the obscure and brightly seek the dawn’s obscurity. Once the heart is illuminated, one knows to pursue the *Dao’s Numerology*. *Dao’s Numerology* refers to the affairs of the *Great Cavern Unity of the Perfected Sovereign*. Some versions write *Seven Awakenings Uphold Numerology Dao*, which is likely erroneous.

Whirlwinds Gather at the Northern Flourishing Hua, Purple Blossoms Sing at the Eastern *＠*, Jade Chimes Harmonize Beyond the Nine Skies, Jade Tallies Summon the Grand Tenuity. The character *＠* is not included in the rhyme schemes of this text, and no pronunciation can be provided. According to the *Scripture on Dispelling Demons, Entering Samadhi Chapter*: *Whirlwinds gleam at the flourishing Lang Hua, Purple Cassia how serene! Jade fruits resound beyond the Nine Skies, Jade tablets summon the Grand Tenuity.* The meaning aligns with the *Cavern Scripture*, suggesting *＠* is a scribal error for *栖* (*qī*).

Luminous Splendor: pronounced *yū wù qiè* (纡勿切). Shi Chong pronounces it *yū wèi qiè* (纡胃切), meaning "elegance." Subsequent instances follow this.

Vast and Subtle Divine Radiance: some versions write *云* (*yún*) for *灵* (*líng*). According to the *Jade Annotations of the Dao Lord*: *Without seeking the subtle cloud radiance, the Golden Chamber cannot be ascended; without reciting the Cavern Chapters, the Jade Guest cannot be seen.* Here, the meanings of *Divine Radiance* and *Cloud Radiance* remain unresolved. This translation follows Huangfu’s version as *灵* (*líng*), pending further inquiry from the Perfected Master.

Forest-Sprinkled: Shi Chong pronounces it *suǒ yí qiè* (所宜切).

Empty Purity Hua: Shi Chong states this is the original name. Huangfu’s version writes *青* (*qīng*).

Pearl-Lush Net: some versions write *殊* (*shū*) for *珠* (*zhū*).

**Highest August Master Purple Dawn Lord’s Scripture of the Dao, Fourth Chapter**

Left No-Blossom Duke, Mysterious Fullness Uncle: some versions write *玄元叔* (*Xuán Yuán Shū*).

Feminine Unity Jade Tablet of the Five Elders Scripture: also called *Mysterious Fullness Uncle*.

**Great Elixir Hidden Writ of the Cavern-True Mystery Scripture**, also called *Mysterious Fullness Uncle*, hence its two names.

*Divine Pass* beneath the *Great Desert*: ancient versions write *mó* (摸).
*Misty Dimness*: pronounced *mò pèi* (莫佩切), meaning faint obscurity.
*Mysterious Mystery Uncle Fire King*: the *Great Elixir Hidden Writ* states: *Lower Mystery Lord Uncle Fire King*, styled *Right Revolving Radiance*. *King*: some versions write *Jade*.
*Mysterious Cavern’s Four Directions*: some versions write *Cavern One Four Directions*.
Styled *Àn Yánchāng*: some versions write *Ān Yánchāng*.
*Hé Yīng*.

The *Great Elixir Hidden Writ* states: *Azure Qi Lord Àn Yánchāng*, styled *Harmonious Infant*.
*Ever Gazing*: ancient versions write [lacuna].
*Dharma Without Wheel*: some versions write *Departing Without Wheel*.

**Fifth Scripture of the Highest August Heavenly Emperor of the Grand Tenuity**
*Cavern-Yang’s Lush Spirit-Treasure, Soul-Generating Golden Radiance within Qi’s Essence*: some versions write *yào yào* (耀耀) for *huàn huàn* (焕焕).
*Uprooting Planting for Posterity’s Afflictions*: some versions write *Uprooting Perishing for Posterity’s Afflictions*.
Shi Chong’s rhyme: pronounced *huán* (还).
*Hewing Severance*: Shi Chong’s first character *zhī* (之) pronounced *yào* (药切), the second *duàn* (断) pronounced *guǎn* (管切). The latter *duàn* (断) and *luò* (落) are synonymous.
*Luminous Brightness Seven-Generation Descendants*: some versions write *huá* (华) for *yè* (叶); Huangfu’s version writes *Míngmíng Qī Yè Sūn* (明明七叶孙); Mao Shan’s version writes *Wěngmíng* (奣明). Shi Chong’s pronunciation and meaning also write *wěng* (奣), pronounced *wēng* (乌猛切).
According to the Perfected’s hidden taboos: *Upper Mystery True Radiance Dao Lord*, taboo name *Wěngméng* (奣萌). *Jíyùn* (集韵) reads *gǔ měng* (古猛切), meaning *bright*. Homophonous with *kuàng* (矿).
*Bóshā Xuán* (＠沙玄): *＠* is homophonous with *bó* (孛).

**Sixth Scripture of the Three Origins Purple Essence Lord**
*Bones Possess Jade Blossoms*: some versions write *yìng* (映).
*Born in Joy*: pronounced *luò* (洛).
*Jade Immortal*: *Jade*: some versions write *Five*.

**Seventh Scripture of the True Yang Origin Elder Mysterious Unity Lord**
*Arising Not Grasping the Staff*: *Mud-Pellet Red Child Right Minister Heavenly Emperor*, named *Qǐ Fēi* (起非); some versions write *Pái* (排).
*Guarding Against Dust-Waves*: some versions write *Pacifying Against Dust-Waves*.
*Supreme Timeliness Not-Son*: some versions write *Supreme Timeliness Above Not-Son*.

**Eighth Scripture of the Upper Origin Grand Simplicity Three Origins Lord**
*Golden Talisman Summons the Transcendent Minister*: some versions write *Xiāng* (乡), likely for rhyme’s sake.
*Highest Vanquisher of Demons Jade Purity King*: Huangfu’s and Mao Shan’s versions both follow the above; some versions write *Highest Divine Empyrean Jade Purity King*.
*He who knows me attains long life; he who preserves me knows no decay*: some versions write *He who knows me lives; he who preserves me knows no decay*.
*Relying on Repelling the Unjust*: *Relying*: some versions write *Serving*.
*Flanking Me*: Shi Chong states the upper character should be *jiā* (夹), meaning *to attend*.
*Kerchiefed in Gold, Girded with Feathers*: the first character *jīn* (巾) pronounced *xìn* (焮切), meaning to cover the head with a kerchief. *Xìn* (焮) pronounced *xiāng zhǎn* (香斩切).
The *Hidden Instructions on Ascending to Perfection* states: *Kerchiefed in Gold* is the name of the Heavenly Perfected’s cap-kerchief. Its design remains unrecorded.

**Ninth Scripture of the Upper Clarity Purple Essence Three Simplicities Lord**

My body sprouts feathered robes, ascending in flight to the Nine Heavens’ thoroughfare—one version omits *my*. Now, according to collation: including *my* completes the phrasing and sense.

Within the Purple Essence’s Flourishing Forest, the *Dao Lord’s Jade Commentary* states: In the Heaven of Upper Clarity’s Purple Essence, there stands a tree whose leaves resemble bamboo yet are crimson, whose blossoms resemble mirrors yet gleam, whose fruits resemble plums yet bear no pit. This is called the Flourishing Forest of Nurtured Splendor. Eating its leaves averts hunger; eating its blossoms confers immortality; eating its fruits grants flight as an immortal. This is what is meant by *crimson trees and cinnabar fruits, their hues illuminating the five viscera*. One version writes *Flourishing* as *Verdant*.

*Cang King*—one version writes *Azure Jade*. *Guarding this Long Night Assembly*—*Guarding*: one version writes *Gradually*. *Thick-lipped*, pronounced *chún*. *The Five Elders hold the sun in their mouths*, *hold* pronounced *zhì*.

**Tenth Scripture of the Azure Numinous Yang Peace Primordial Lord**
*Gazing toward Prosperity’s Exhaustion*—one version writes *Visiting*. *Linked kalpas give birth*—*kalpas*: one version writes *bó*.

**Tenth Scripture of the August Clarity Cavern-Realized Dao Lord**
*Jade Clarity Cavern-Luminous Womb King*—one version omits *Luminous*. *Returning Simplicity fills*—one version writes *Primordial*. *Long Heaven gives birth*—one version writes *Long Life Heaven*. *Upright Flourishing Branches*—these three characters are the inner names of the Three Primordial Lords. **Twelfth Scripture of the Highest Great Simplicity Lord**
Titled *Northern Terrace Lord*—one version omits *Lord*. *Returning Gold to the Great Radiance Land*—one version writes *Minister*. *Sun’s Brightness Eight Ascensions*—the *Secret Essentials of Cultivating Perfection* states: The Perfected Lord within the sun is styled *Lofty Ascending Brightness*. One version writes *Sun’s Splendor Eight Ascensions*. The *Dao Lord’s Jade Commentary* states: *Sun’s Splendor* is the name of the sun’s spirit; *Eight Ascensions* is the name of a tree within the moon. There are eight such trees, all dwelling in the moon. Now, the meanings of *Brightness* and *Splendor* remain unresolved; here we follow Huangfu’s version, writing *Brightness*. *Harmonizing Return to Fall*—one version writes *Fall* as *End*. *Knots unfurl eternally*—one version writes *Knots* as *Auspicious*.

**Thirteenth Scripture of the August Supreme Four Elders Within the Dao Lord**
*Revolving winds blend the Emperor’s heart*—one version writes *Lingering winds blend the Emperor’s heart*. Titled *Longevity’s Leisurely Abundance*—one version writes *Assistance*. Also called *Limpid Confluence Still*—one version writes *Limpid Increasing Still*, another writes *Limpid Increasing Pavilion*. *Arising blessings ascend to the dawn spirits*—one version writes *Transcending blessings*. *Hand grasping the register*—one version writes *green*. *Refining the po in the Hollow Cavern*—Shi Chong writes *Cavern*, homophonous. *The Moon Emperor’s merit*—the *Dao Lord’s Jade Commentary* states: *The Moon Emperor announces merit*. One version writes *Sun Emperor*, likely in error. *Strumming gold, ringing bells*—the *Dao Lord’s Jade Commentary* states: *Strumming gold, ringing bells*. One version writes *Strumming the zither, ringing bells*.

**Fourteenth Scripture of the Jade Dawn Supreme Great Dao Lord**
*White light* [two characters illegible]—Shi Chong reads *yāng*. *Clothing me*—*clothing* pronounced *yì*. *Layered branches flow into the mysterious*—one version writes *Manifest Blessings flow into the mysterious*. *Five Peaks’ flourishing splendor*—one version writes *living splendor*. *Crossing the Dharma complete*—one version writes *complete* as *command*.

**Fifteenth Scripture of the Great Clarity Great Dao Lord**
*Radiant harmony*—Shi Chong reads the first character *xī* as *zhīqí*, meaning *harmony*; the second character *qià* as *yí*, meaning *nurturing*. *Firming the body, guarding the passes*—one version writes *gates*. *Mysterious Mother Uncle Fire King*—one version writes *Jade*. *Further blending*—Shi Chong reads the first character *gēng*, the second *hùn*; the same thereafter. *Uprooting kalpas from Ā*—one version writes *Form kalpas from Ā*.

**Sixteenth Scripture of the Supreme Ultimate Great Dao Primordial Radiance Lord**
*Fat membranes*—Shi Chong writes *High Curtains*, pronounced *gāomò*. *Raising the essentials*—pronounced *yāo*, the same thereafter. *The Emperor’s chamber blends the body into one, the Dao into ten thousand parts*—one version writes *The Emperor’s chamber blends into one*. *The six palaces gleam brightly*—one version writes *splendor*. *Firmly halting the body*—one version writes *firmly* as *nation*.

**Seventeenth Scripture of the August Primordial Purple Numinous Primordial Lord**
*Five talismans open the door*—one version writes *pái*. Ancient scriptures often write *door* as *pái*, pronounced *fēi*.

**Eighteenth Scripture of the Non-Ultimate Central Perfected Supreme Elder Lord**
*Mysterious fullness of the Primordial Essence qi*—one version writes *Mysterious Primordial Primordial Essence announces*. *Within the womb planting ghostly calamities*—one version writes *accumulating ghosts*. *His sageliness is called* [one character illegible]—Shi Chong reads the first character *yuè*, the second *gē*. Huangfu’s version writes *song*, which is incorrect. *His perfection is called* [one character illegible]—Shi Chong reads *wūhóng*; Huangfu’s version writes *hóng*, one version writes *hóng*. *Left is pronounced* [one character illegible]—one version writes *sun*. *Father pacifies and resides*—*right is pronounced* [one character illegible], one version writes *moon*. *Mother extends essence*—writing *sun and moon* is likely in error. *All receive the Emperor’s singular grace*—one version omits *singular*. *Receiving years and blessings*—one version writes *emoluments*.

**Nineteenth Scripture of the Central Yellow Elder Lord**
*Mysterious leaves attain Yellow Peace*—one version writes *leaves* as *blossoms*. *Flowing life arises blessings*—one version writes *arises* as *transcends*. *Dispersing grievances*—Shi Chong writes *resentments*, pronounced *yuān*. *Grasping and upholding the Jade Clarity guests*—one version writes *guests* as *lords*. *Comet connects*—ancient versions often write *learn*, pronounced *bó*. One version writes *Comet constantly connects*. *Wealth* [one character illegible] *Primordial*—one version writes *Wealth* as *Blessings*, one writes *harm*, one writes [one character illegible] as *kalpa*.

**Twentieth Scripture of the Azure Essence Upper Perfected Inner Radiance Lord**
*Reversing aging, giving birth to luxuriance*—*luxuriance* pronounced *wěng*.

**Lush and dense**—descriptive of flourishing grasses and trees. Shi Chong harmonizes the rhyme, reading *wēng*.
**Mugwort visage**—*mugwort* signifies old age.
*Restoring whiteness, reverting to infant dawn*—one version writes *infant* as *child*.
**Morning lamp of talismanic registers**—Chapter Eight of the Scripture states: *The morning lamp broadens numinous awareness*. According to the Jade Commentary of the Dao Lord: *The morning lamp is the luminous qi-light within the Jade Perfected Heaven, jointly illuminating the Three Origin Terraces*. Though the Jade Commentary does not explicate this in the twentieth chapter, it likely carries this meaning. One version writes *morning ascent*; the two interpretations remain unresolved, and here we follow Huangfu’s version as *morning lamp*.
**Daoist Immortal King**—one version writes *King* as *August*.
**Clothed and adorned**—Shi Chong’s upper pronunciation reads *pī*.
**Jade table**—Shi Chong harmonizes the rhyme, reading *ān*.

**Twenty-First Scripture of the Grand Yang Nine Radiance Jade Worthiness Primordial Lord**
*Jade contract bestowed upon the seven ancestors*—one version writes *bestowed* as *clothed*.
*Opening the Yin to the Grand Vastness*—one version writes *vastness* as *urgency*.
**Whirlwind radiance**—upper character read *bì yáo*.
**Twenty-Second Scripture of the Grand Beginning Nine Essences Golden Florescence Radiance Primordial Lord**
**Luminous and bright**—pronounced *yù*.
**Flowing swiftly**—read *yú bǐ* or *gǔ mò*, descriptive of water’s movement.
*Serene stillness of the Muddy Pellet*—one version writes *serene* as *essence*.
*Within the Nine Heavens*—one version writes *within* as *gate*.
**Darkness’s second**—one version writes *darkness* as *abyss*.
*Extending life’s jade*—one version writes *jade* as *king*.

**Twenty-Third Scripture of the Nine August Upper Perfected Controller of Destiny Lord**
**Resplendent and radiant**—upper character read *hǔ guǎng*, lower *yún zhé*.
**Fortune’s canopy**—pronounced *fāng jiù*.
One version writes *tread*, another *felicity*.
*Five spirits’ names emit smoke*—one version writes *emit knots*; the two interpretations remain unresolved, and here we follow Huangfu’s version as *smoke*. According to the *Inner Perfected Scripture of the Golden Chamber*: *The Controller of Destiny’s essence-soul emits the Smoky Child*.
**Joy**—pronounced *luò*.
*Blood defilements extinguished and leveled*—one version writes *extinguished* as *pervaded*.
*Raising fortune to the Three Clarities*—one version writes *raising* as *transcending*.
*Green Revolving cuts through the dark*—according to the *Names of the Hundred Spirits*, the Heavenly Emperor’s Nine Passes Soul is called *Green Revolving Dao*. One version writes *Green Fortune*, likely in error.
*Grand Unity blends life*—one version writes *Grand Blending One generates life*, likely in error.
*Grasping the hall’s reach*—one version writes *establishing*.
*Primordial subtlety’s numen*—one version writes *subtlety* as [illegible].

**Twenty-Fourth Scripture of the Heavenly August Upper Perfected Jade Florescence Three Origins Lord**
**Lower abdomen**—upper character read *shí zhào*.
In Huangfu’s version, all instances of *lower abdomen* are written as *small abdomen*.
*Revolving form precedes the Emperor*—one version writes *light*.
*Preserving release and riding*—one version writes *preserving stillness and descending*.

**Twenty-Fifth Scripture of the Grand Unity Upper Origin Prohibitions Lord**
**Brilliant and radiant**—one version writes *dispersing*.
**Chariot-beam of the Solar August Lord**—these three characters are the inner name of the Solar August Lord; when reciting to this point, silently intone them thrice. The above nineteen characters appear in Huangfu’s version; other versions are all deficient.

**Twenty-Sixth Scripture of the Primordial Void Yellow Chamber Perfected Dawn Lord**
*Moon*—one version writes *sun*.
*Central Peach Lord’s radiance fills*—the Perfected Qi of the *moon*—one version writes *sun*.
*Its splendor’s hue*—*moon*—one version writes *sun*.
*Central Name fills*—the *Nine Perfected Central Scripture* states: *The youth of the right hand is named Fills*. Since it pertains to the right hand, it should be *moon*; some write *sun*, likely in error.
*Drawing the moon’s radiant qi*—one version writes *sun’s radiance*.
*Opening and illuminating the eight* [illegible]—one version writes *keen*.
*Enabling my feathered register before the Jade Emperor*—according to the Jade Commentary of the Dao Lord: *Those who attain the Dao of emptiness and nonbeing have their feathered tally inscribed, ascending before the Jade Emperor, where the Five Elders fix the talisman in the Jade Palace’s hall*. One version writes *feathered slip*.
**Dragon banner**—one version writes *banner*.
*Transferred through kalpas*—one version writes *transferred* as *transported*.

**Twenty-Seventh Scripture of the Grand Ultimate Lord of the Four Perfected Ones**
**Essence’s luster**—one version writes *luster* as *crystal*, pronounced *yīng*.
**Pupil’s brightness**—Shi Chong states it should be written as *pupil*.
**Unbinding**—pronounced *hú mài*.
*Sleeping and rising in fortune*—one version writes *sleeping and rising in entanglement*.

**Twenty-Eighth Scripture of the Central Four Dipper Perfected Seven Dawns Scattered Florescence Lord**
**Scattered florescence, flying florescence, florescence scattered**—*florescence* pronounced *huā* throughout.
*Born within the Emperor’s homeland of the Central Mystery*—one version writes *Emperor’s minister*.
*Grand Unity’s blended wind*—one version writes *blended* as *brandished*.
*Aligning with my spirit*—one version writes *aligning* as *north*.
*Three Essences’ firmament above*—according to the *Names of the Hundred Spirits*, the *Three Essences Elder Lord’s Firmament Above*. One version adds *Primordial* below *above*; this may better accord with the meaning.
*The Elder Lord’s spirit generates the Dao, securing my soul’s carefree wandering*—one version writes *soul* as *spirit*.
*Preserving my destiny’s six unions of the brain*—*nǎo* pronounced *nǎo*; one version writes *unions* as *palace*.
*White qi densely layered*—one version writes *layered* as *mist*.
**Fresh and winding mystery**—one version writes *winding* as *revolving*.

**Twenty-Ninth Scripture of the Central Dawn Yellow Radiance Primordial Lord**
*Two Elders at the left and right; the Emperor’s soul cannot be divided*—according to the *Names of the Hundred Spirits*, the *Two Elders* refer to the *Three Essences Elder Lord’s Firmament Above* and the *Central Mystery Primordial Elder Lord Lin Xufu*. The *Emperor’s soul* refers to the *Heavenly Register Emperor Soul Illuminating the Nameless*. One version writes *Three Elders at the left and right directions; the Emperor’s soul cannot but be divided*, likely in error.
*Child perpetually preserves prosperity*—one version writes *preserves the child’s eternal prosperity*.

**Thirtieth Scripture of the Golden Watchtower Posterior Sage Grand Peace Li Perfected Heavenly Emperor Upper Radiance Lord**
**Grand Emperor of the Eight Numinous Kings**—one version writes *Jade*.
*Revolving and uniting the Emperor’s ministers*—one version writes *homeland*.
**Planting years**—pronounced *zhī yòng*.
*Thus becoming an infant*—one version writes *moon as infant*.

**Thirty-First Scripture of the Grand Void Posterior Sage Primordial Radiance Pengshi Perfected Lord**
*Grand Void’s empty radiance*—according to the Jade Commentary of the Dao Lord: *Within the Grand Void Heaven lies a fiery mountain named the Empty Radiance Mountain*. One version writes *Primordial Radiance*, likely in error.
*Nine clouds close the layered gates*—one version writes *bolts*, then *gates*.
**Gate’s base**—Shi Chong harmonizes the rhyme, reading *hù*.
*Disasters and harms daily removed*—one version writes *removed* as *governed*.

**Thirty-Second Scripture of the Grand Profound Capital Nine Qi Elder Lord Master Immortal Lord**

**Divine Hut**—pronounced *lǘ*, meaning *abode*. Ancient scriptures often write *hut* as *lú*, pronounced *lú*.
**Nine Zeng Ascend the Blessing Hall**—Shi Chong writes *wilderness*, pronounced *qū*.
**Northern Banquet of Supreme Clarity**—one version writes *Northern* as *Comparative*.
**Ever-Aiding Golden Chamber**—one version writes *aiding* as *ascending*.

**Thirty-Third Scripture of the Supreme Clarity Eight August Elder Lord**
**Essential Numinosity**—the first character read in the *yáo* tone, meaning *to summon*.
**Years Prosper**—Shi Chong reads *xǔ-gēng*, Huangfu’s version writes *enjoy*; *pursued by radiance*—one version writes *Dao*, another *pursued*.
**Crossing the Link**—one version writes *transmitting*.
**Attaining Wholeness**—one version writes *gold*.

**Thirty-Fourth Scripture of the Eastern Florescence Square Reservoir Palace High Dawn Master Jade Guardian King Azure Lad**
**Jade Guardian**—one version writes *treasure*.
**Controller of Destinies, Essence-Soul, Smoke-Emitter**—one version writes *Smoke-Tether*. According to the *Inner True Scripture of the Golden Chamber*, it reads *Controller of Destinies, Essence-Soul, Smoke-Emitter*.
**Resplendent Cavern**—one version writes *resplendent and radiant*.
**Dark Unraveling of the Great Demon’s Nature**—one version writes *Supreme Here Great Demon’s Nature*.
**Numinous Banner Governing the Corporeal Soul**—one version writes *soul*.
**Three Paths Blocked and Severed**—one version writes *Three Paths Severed and Broken*.
**Death-qi**—one version writes *death-planting*.

**Thirty-Fifth Scripture of the Fusang Grand Thearch Nine Elder Immortal August Lord**
**Inferior Mystery Mysterious Mother Uncle Fire King**—one version writes *Inferior Mystery Primordial Mother Uncle Fire Engenderer*; another writes *Inferior Mystery Mysterious Mother Uncle Fire King*. **Sun Bright Perfected**—the first character read in the *zhì* tone.
**Grand Thearch Essence-Soul Yang Hall King**—one version writes *Lord*.
**Radiant Crown**—pronounced *guàn*.

**Thirty-Sixth Scripture of the Lesser Existence Jade Perfected Myriad Florescence Master Chart King Lord**
**Door Hollow**—ancient scriptures often write *kū* as *jué*. Shi Chong reads *kū*; modern versions simply write *kū*.
**Rotten Bones Receive Renewed Shedding**—Shi Chong reads *shuō*, explaining it as the cicada shedding its skin. The *Collected Rhymes* states: *tuì* means *fùyù*; *fùyù* is the cicada’s molting.
**Square Transcendence Suspected**—one version writes *transcendence* as *arising*.

**Thirty-Seventh Scripture of the Perfected Lords of the Twenty-Nine True Counts of the Dark Continent, Overseers of Prohibitions**
*Bladder*—pronounced *páng* or *guāng*.

**Central Yellow Thearch Containing Radiance Dew**—Most versions of the *Thirty-Seventh Chapter: Method of Visualizing the Five Thearchs* include only the Eastern, Southern, Western, and Northern Thearchs, collectively termed the *Five Thearchs*, but omit the name of the Central Yellow Thearch. Only the edition transmitted by Master Guanmiao, a *Three Caverns* Dharma Master, preserves this title, *Central Yellow Thearch Containing Radiance Dew*, thereby completing the visualization method. Further inquiries were made by the Perfected Master Geng.

*Double Veil*—the first character read in the *zhí-lóng* tone, the second pronounced *mì*; a cloth covering for food, also written as *幎*.
*Robes*—the first character pronounced *pī*.
*Girdle Pendant*—the first character read in the *yāo* tone; some versions write *waist*.
*Embroidered Cloak*—Shi Chong harmonizes the rhyme, pronouncing it *pī*.
*Canopy*—the first character read in the *yú-bēi* tone; a tent.
*Lan-gan*—pronounced *lán* or *gān*.
*Revolving Repository*—read in the departing tone.
*Loom*—one version writes *mechanism*.
*Circulating the Grand Unity*—one version writes *penetrating circulation*.
*Generating the Two Modes in Equilibrium*—one version writes *Two Modes*.
*Feeding Mud*—the first character pronounced *bù*.
*Primordial Simplicity Lord of Shared Heart*—one version writes *qi* for *simplicity*.
*Enthroned as a Celestial Lord*—one version writes *Grand* for *Celestial*.
*Unlocking the Flower of Spirit*—one version writes *closing* for *unlocking*.
*Grand Epoch Primordium*—one version writes *Great* for *Grand*.

**Thirty-Eighth Scripture of the Grand Primordium Dawn Center Lord, Engraved in the Jade Portal of the Grotto Palace on Mount Emei, the Grand Simplicity Lord**
*Emei*—alternatively written as *Emei*.
*Imperial Minister Inscribing Essence*—one version writes *diligence* for *inscribing*.
*Threefold Splendor Bough*—pronounced *gē*.
*Grand Primordium Grand Simplicity Cavern Radiance Dark Mystery*—According to the *Jade Commentary* of the Perfected Lord: *Grand Nonbeing* lies beyond *Cavern Radiance*; *Grand Simplicity* resides above *Dark Mystery*. The Nine Palaces array their Golden Gates in the heavens of *Grand Simplicity*, while the Vermilion Towers stand sevenfold in the courts of *Grand Nonbeing*. One version writes *Grand Simplicity Cavern Radiance, Emerging from Darkness and Entering Mystery*, which appears erroneous.
*Three and Five Flowing Transformations*—one version writes *flowing distribution*, likely for rhyme, though the following text already contains *the hundred spirits proclaim*, and the Huangfu edition also writes *transformations*.
*White Prime Overseer of the Moon’s Dusk*—one version writes *moon’s measure*; another, *moonlit night*.
*Profound Mystery Subtle Awakening*—one version writes *subtle* for *subtle mystery*.

**Thirty-Ninth Scripture of the Ninefold Numinous Perfected Immortal Mother of the Western Prime Tortoise Mountain, the Azure Gold Elixir Empress**
*Infant Ignorance*—ancient scriptures often write *蒙*; Shi Chong pronounces it *méng*.
*Branches*—Shi Chong explains: *accumulated branches* means *accumulated generations*.
*Flourishing*—read in the *suǒ-zhēn* tone; an appearance of abundance.
*Receiving the Luminous Descent*—one version writes *descend* for *descent*.

According to the second fascicle of the *Concealed Instructions on Ascending Perfection*, in the section on *Scriptural and Commentarial Conventions*: The *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern* now circulates in two versions. One is a large scroll, prefaced by the *Method of Revolving Wind and Blending Union*, but its diction and purport are spurious and deceptive. The other consists solely of thirty-nine chapters, within which a few passages align with those spoken by the *Right Consort*, yet they are intermingled and indistinguishable. Only by personally examining the authentic edition can one follow it properly. It is also said that those who obtained the thirty-nine chapters of Yang and Xu found them no different from the common small edition. Since I have not seen it with my own eyes, I cannot judge its authenticity, but it is fitting to transcribe it to complete the catalog. There is also a *Jade Commentary* in one fascicle, which briefly explicates the essentials of the *Cavern Scripture* and may likewise be copied.

Furthermore, according to the *Azure Essentials Purple Writ of the Golden Root Scripture*, the Central Yellow Venerable Lord states: Whoever beholds the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern in Thirty-Nine Chapters* shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight. Yet some who cultivate it achieve no success after years of practice and claim the scripture is not authentic. This is entirely due to their failure to present a *Golden Tablet* to the Azure Palace or offer a *Jade Memorandum* to the Thearch. Without the descent of true numina, they are instead visited by celestial demons, thus yielding no response and vainly obtaining only spirit scriptures, which likewise lead to no accomplishment. Had they first memorialized the *Golden Tablet* at the Azure Palace and presented the *Jade Memorandum* to the Thearch, receiving the attendance of the *Golden Dawn Jade Lads* and *Western Flower Jade Maidens* to guard the numinous writ, and had it universally proclaimed throughout the heavens so that the Three Realms extolled its virtue and chanted its verses ten thousand times—how could they fail to evoke the response of jade chariots and purple carriages?

Here ends the *Jade Instructions on the Sounds and Meanings of the Great Cavern Perfect Scripture of Highest Clarity*.

**Scripture Title:** *Jade Exegesis and Phonetic Gloss of the Supreme Clarity Great Cavern Perfected Scripture*
**Author:** Daoist Chen Jingyuan of the Northern Song

**Preface to the *Jade Exegesis and Phonetic Gloss of the Supreme Clarity Great Cavern Perfected Scripture***

Composed by Chen Jingyuan, Disciple of the Three Radiant Caverns of the Great Cavern, Perfected Master of True Stillness, and Recipient of the Purple Robe

The *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* hold a title of solemn reverence, standing foremost among the Three Caverns’ treasured scriptures. Its numinous verses and secret incantations, sealed in jade tablets and concealed in hidden writings, are recorded in full detail.

Since the Western City’s Lord of Total Perfection and the Southern Culmen’s Purple Prime Lady bestowed it upon the Perfected One of Pure Emptiness, who in turn transmitted it to Madame Wei of Southern Marchmount, it has been said: “Should you not dwell in the mountains, concealing yourself in pure retreat and voiding the center through breath-regulation, then the *Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* must not be recited recklessly.”

The reason for this is that its wondrous tones resonate through nine heavens, its true sounds soar in lofty chant. The qi of its text intermingles with the Jade Void in profound mystery, its rosy savor harmonizes with the Great Yang in full splendor. When lips move to utter it, jade efflorescence instantly arrives; when its sacred lines are intoned, one joins in covenant with the Most High. In stillness, with hands clasped in reverence, the Purple Chamber reveals itself; in focused contemplation of one’s aspirations, all kindred spirits respond in resonance.

Thus, the seven ancestors gain blessings, receive registers of immortal palaces, transcend the ranks of hidden ghosts, and together feast in the Vermilion Mound. This scripture’s sublimity soars, steering the chariot of dawn’s ascent, riding the Way of the luminous dragon—far beyond the reach of those mired in the dust of mundane custom.

Should one recite it while still entangled in worldly affairs, the Three Officials and the Northern Emperor will disrupt its tones, and the radiant listener, tainted by impure qi, will fail to attain the resplendent resonance of Supreme Clarity or harmonize the voice with the numinous chambers of the Purple Culmen.

The *Azure Essentials and Purple Writ* of the Central Yellow Venerable Lord states: “To behold the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Perfected Scripture* is to ascend to heaven in broad daylight.” Yet some who cultivate it accumulate years without fruition and then claim the scripture is not true. This is entirely due to their names lacking inscription on the Golden Tablet of the Eastern Flower or the Jade Slip of the Golden Watchtower. The true numina do not descend for them, and instead, celestial demons approach, resulting in no responsive efficacy. Though they may obtain spirit-scriptures, they will never succeed.

Had they first memorialized the Golden Tablet to the Azure Palace and presented the Jade Slip to the Thearch-Emperor, securing the attendance of the Golden Dawn Jade Lads and the Western Flower Jade Maidens to guard the numinous text, and had all heavens and earths, the three realms, praised and chanted its verses ten thousand times—how could they not have evoked the response of the jade chariot and purple carriage?

Since this scripture descended into the world, only the Perfected Yang and Xu of Mount Juqu and Master Sima the Refiner of Mount Wangwu, along with successive generations of eminent Daoist adepts, have adhered to its precepts, transmitting it through sworn covenants. The oral instructions for its recitation and the esoteric subtleties of its integration were secretly imparted, enabling them to inscribe their names in the golden register and tread the luminous paths of Supreme Clarity.

Yet today, the true wind has scattered and faded, false recluses dwell in mountain retreats, the standards of the Dao are unheard, the rites between master and disciple have lapsed, and the teachings have declined—nothing is more grievous than this.

Jingyuan left home in childhood, sought the Dao in youth, and wandered for thirty years, presiding over the essentials for over a decade. In old age, I returned to Mount Mao, built a hut, and engaged in repentance. I lamented my meager karmic affinity for the Dao and the weight of my worldly karma. Though I diligently studied the scriptures, I never encountered a true master. How could I dare unseal and recite the Cavern Scripture?

Thus, I purified body and mind, devoted myself to reverence and purity, and broadly sought ancient editions. First, I examined and verified them myself, poring over them in silence, repeatedly analyzing and constructing their meaning. Not a single phrase or character was overlooked.

Yet where two interpretations clashed, my perplexity only deepened—such as the case of *fa* (發) being miswritten as *fa yan* (發煙). Or where characters were altered in their components or forms, becoming confused and inconsistent—such as *qi* (栖) written as *@*, or *@* written as *ge* (歌).

This is because private copyists and illicit transmissions have perpetuated errors through successive generations. I have therefore taken the editions used by earlier practitioners—the Three Caverns Dharma Master, Master of Mystical Observation, Zhu Ziying, and the Three Caverns Dharma Master, Grand Master of Profound Mystery, Huangfu Xiji, both reciters of the Cavern Scripture and contemporaries of the Tiansheng era—as well as the editions preserved at Mount Mao’s repository. Comparing them with the hidden writings, I have compiled this phonetic gloss and exegesis, elucidating discrepancies and roughly resolving doubts. I dare not present this as definitive Dharma teaching, but merely record what I have examined for my own reference.

After three months of purifying my heart in retreat, I transcribed a copy of the *Jade Exegesis of the Cavern Scripture*, which I now reverently contemplate morning and evening. I await the numinous ones to bestow it according to the proper precepts, thereby fulfilling my long-cherished aspiration.

---

chunks.original_text: 玦玦，叶韵音央，见唐光禄大夫太清观主史崇《一切道经音义》。 攘据，上汝羊切，下居御切，持也。 杖幡，上直亮切、持也。 或作仗，音同。 摄邪，似嗟切，古本作邪。 檄落，上刑狄切，作激，古历或作敷。 云璈，音遨。 史崇云：大琴也。 百和合唱，赤亮切，或作咽。 史崇云：当作烟。 激无，上古历切。 四嵎，音隅。 迅辔，上峻信二音，疾也。 下兵媚切。 整控，上之郢切，下苦贡切。 流盼，普苋切，古本作眄。 史崇音面。 协神飘津坡，史崇作协晨。 褰趾，上去焉切，下音止，足也。 褰或作骞。 紫軿，音瓶，车也。 烟洒，所下切。 史崇所绮、所寄二切。 汛也，落也。 八冥，音溟。 妙观，古段切。 步北元，茅山本作涉北元。 掇日，上多活切。 连更，音庚。 凄凄，音妻，或作凄。 莽莽，莫党切，广大无涯极之貌。 数来，上色句切。 重虚馆，史崇馆作观。 玉髓，息委切。 参闻，上仓含切； 下声参同。 监试，上古衔切，临也。 下监庭同。 载胜，音升。 史崇作戴胜。 秉简，上补永切，持也。 来冠，古玩切。 回风，上胡隈切，说文转也，俗作迥，非是。 旧作徊，徘徊不进之貌。 说文本作裴回，宽衣也，取其裴回之状。 他皆类此。 啜误，上株多切，多言不止谓之啜。 或作掇，非是也。 平生，说文止也。

*Rǎngjù* (攘據): the first character is pronounced *rǔ yáng qiè* (汝羊切), the second *jū yù qiè* (居御切), meaning "to grasp."

*Zhàngfān* (杖幡): the first character is pronounced *zhí liàng qiè* (直亮切), meaning "to hold." Alternatively written as *仗* (*zhàng*), same pronunciation.

*Shèxié* (攝邪): pronounced *sì jiē qiè* (似嗟切), ancient editions wrote it as *邪*.

*Xílào* (檄落): the first character is pronounced *xíng dí qiè* (刑狄切), written as *激* (*jī*); in ancient calendars, it may also be written as *敷*.

*Yúnao* (云璈): pronounced *áo* (遨). Shi Chong states: "a great zither."

*Bǎihé héchàng* (百和合唱): pronounced *chì liàng qiè* (赤亮切), or written as *咽*. Shi Chong states: "should be written as *烟* (*yān*)."

*Jīwú* (激無): the first character is pronounced *gǔ lì qiè* (古歷切).

*Sìyú* (四嵎): pronounced *yú* (隅).

*Zhěngkòng* (整控): the first character is pronounced *zhī yǐng qiè* (之郢切), the second *kǔ gòng qiè* (苦贡切).

*Liúpàn* (流盼): pronounced *pǔ xiàn qiè* (普苋切), ancient editions wrote it as *眄*. Shi Chong pronounces it *miàn* (面).

*Qiānzhǐ* (褰趾): the first character is pronounced *qù yān qiè* (去焉切), the second *zhǐ* (止), meaning "foot." *褰* may also be written as *骞*.

*Zǐpíng* (紫軿): pronounced *píng* (瓶), meaning "chariot."

*Yānsǎ* (烟洒): pronounced *suǒ xià qiè* (所下切). Shi Chong gives two pronunciations: *suǒ qǐ qiè* (所绮切) and *suǒ jì qiè* (所寄切), meaning "to scatter" or "to fall."

*Bāmíng* (八冥): pronounced *míng* (溟).

*Miàoguān* (妙观): pronounced *gǔ duàn qiè* (古段切).

*Duōrì* (掇日): the first character is pronounced *duō huó qiè* (多活切).

*Liángēng* (连更): pronounced *gēng* (庚).

*Qīqī* (凄凄): pronounced *qī* (妻), or written as *凄*.

*Mǎngmǎng* (莽莽): pronounced *mò dǎng qiè* (莫党切), describing a vast and boundless expanse.

*Shùlái* (数来): the first character is pronounced *sè jù qiè* (色句切).

*Chóngxū guǎn* (重虚馆): Shi Chong writes *馆* as *观* (*guàn*).

*Yùsuǐ* (玉髓): pronounced *xī wěi qiè* (息委切).

*Cānwén* (参闻): the first character is pronounced *cāng hán qiè* (仓含切); the second is pronounced as in *shēng cān tóng* (声参同).

*Jiānshì* (监试): the first character is pronounced *gǔ xián qiè* (古衔切), meaning "to oversee"; the second character is the same as in *jiān tíng* (监庭).

*Zàishèng* (载胜): pronounced *shēng* (升). Shi Chong writes it as *戴胜* (*dàishèng*).

*Bǐngjiǎn* (秉简): the first character is pronounced *bǔ yǒng qiè* (补永切), meaning "to hold."

*Láiguān* (来冠): pronounced *gǔ wàn qiè* (古玩切).

*Huífēng* (回风): the first character is pronounced *hú wēi qiè* (胡隈切). The *Shuowen* states it means "to turn"; the vulgar writing *迥* (*jiǒng*) is incorrect. Formerly written as *徊* (*huái*), describing a lingering, non-advancing motion. The *Shuowen* originally wrote it as *裴回* (*péihuí*), meaning "loose robes," capturing the sense of their billowing. Other instances follow this pattern.

*Chuòwù* (啜误): the first character is pronounced *zhū duō qiè* (株多切), meaning "to chatter endlessly." Written as *掇* (*duō*) is incorrect.

*Píngshēng* (平生): as defined in the *Shuowen*, "to cease."

chunks.original_text: 头冠，古玩切，弁冕之总名。 他皆类此。 天湄，昱悲切，水涯也。 薄云，上音博，迫也。 四岭，古本作领，后同。 重扉，上直龙切，下音非，古本作扉，或音排，排或音扉。 他同此。 兽骋，丑郢切。 人互，胡故切，俗作无，非是。 干景精，太微小童名，一作千景精。 神麾，呼为切，旗属也。 一本作魔，非是。 裴回，旧本并作徘徊，今并依说文，改作裴回。 后更不音。 飙轮，上必遥切。 毫荟，乌外切，草盛貌。 蓊蔼，上乌董切，下於盖切，后同。 元阳部命门，一本作都命门。 侍明窗，史崇作窗，初江切。 一本作聪。 婴蒙，古本作蒙，后同。 晏盼，普苋切，说文引诗：美目盼兮。 古本盼、眄，一例作眄。 眄，说文：目偏合也。 一曰邪视，与盼相乖，后以义求之。 乐子，上音洛，下同。 解体，胡买切，了悟也。 四射，史崇食亦切，或作四谢，非是。 高上埼，史崇音奇，曲岸也。 一本作琦。 啸咤，或作咤，知加、陟嫁二切。 说文：叱，怒也。 咄，当没切。 说文呵也，叱也。 嗟顷，上咨鸦切。 说文咨也。 一曰痛惜，一去颖切。 倏，式竹切，疾也，走也。 古本作鲦。 说文：青黑缯，发白色也。 一曰黑色。 欻，许勿切。 说文：有所吹起。 铁熊，斑麋切。 玃天，厥缚切，天兽名。 一本作攫。 啖毒，徒滥切，食也。 皛，史崇胡了切，又音魄。 ，史崇音巴。 按诸真隐讳云：北酆都鬼相魂，名四天皛。 崩颓，杜回切。 史崇云：字宜作墤。 弇晖，上衣检切。 史崇云：上宜作蚀，日月相侵也。 高上虚皇君道经第一 长契一运，古本一作壹。 七世，一本作七祖。 投闲，一本作关。 陵梵，闻承切。 古本陵、凌，一例作凌，后同。 世发玉兰，一本作简。 八曜，一本作晖。 随风离根配，迁基达变入玄，一本作迁棋达变入玄元，一本有元素二字，或读者连下句云：元素高上神霄玉清王。 茅山藏本无元素二字。 今以茅山藏本为定。 雌雄寄神化，一本寄作奇。 百浑，奇混切。 古本混作矫，俱入帝堂会，按道君玉注云：易者善，九天之上西北之门名也。 若既登易有之门，乃得升帝堂之会室。 今按室字虽与上文协韵，宜从玉注，以会字为正。 波逮台，一本作彼建台。 上皇玉虚君道经第二 爓爓，音艳，光也。 千劫始一周，一本作十劫始一周。 皇上玉帝君道经第三 玉帝有玄上之幡，制命九天之阶，茅山本并无之字。 七觉承道数，按道君玉注云：七觉重悟幽冥，朗寻昧旦，既心晓朗然，乃知寻呼道数。 道数者，洞真帝一大洞之事也。 一本作七觉承数道，恐误。 飙集北停华，紫英唱东＠，琳和九霄外，玉符征太微，＠，篇韵并不收，无音可释。 按消魔经入定品云：飙粲停琅华，紫桂何栖栖，琳实呜九霄，玉节征太微，义与洞经同，恐＠是栖传写之误。 光蔚，纡勿切。 史崇纡胃切，文也。 后同。 眇眇灵景无，灵，一本作云。 按道君玉注云：自非眇寻云景而金房不登，自非重诵洞章而玉宾不见也。 今详灵景、云景二义未决，且从皇甫本作灵，以竣真师请问质疑。 森洒，史崇所宜切。 空清华，史崇云：本名也。 皇甫本作青。 珠郁罗，一本珠作殊。 上皇先生紫晨君道经第四 左无英公子玄充叔，一本作玄元叔。 雌一玉检五老经，亦云玄元叔。

Celestial Shore: pronounced *yù bēi qiè* (昱悲切), the edge of water.

Thin Clouds: the first character is pronounced *bó* (博), meaning "to press close."

Four Ridges: originally written as *领* (*lǐng*); subsequent instances follow this.

Double Doors: the first character is pronounced *zhí lóng qiè* (直龙切), the second *fēi* (非). Originally written as *扉* (*fēi*); some pronounce it *pái* (排), and *排* may also be pronounced *fēi* (扉). Other instances follow this pattern.

Beast Galloping: pronounced *chǒu yǐng qiè* (丑郢切).

Human Intertwining: pronounced *hú gù qiè* (胡故切); the vulgar writing *无* (*wú*) is incorrect.

Lingering: former versions uniformly wrote *徘徊* (*páihuái*); now all follow the *Shuowen* and are amended to *裴回* (*péihuí*). No further pronunciations are provided hereafter.

Whirlwind Wheel: the first character is pronounced *bì yáo qiè* (必遥切).

Primal Yang Department Gate of Life: some versions write *Metropolis Gate of Life*.

Attending the Bright Window: Shi Chong writes it as *窗* (*chuāng*), pronounced *chū jiāng qiè* (初江切). Some versions write *聪* (*cōng*).
